metadata.case_name: Raja of Puri v. State of Orissa

facts.text: The Shri Jagannath Temple at Puri is an ancient institution of unique and national importance, attracting pilgrims from all over India.
Before British conquest in 1803, Temple managed by Muslim rulers directly through Hindu employees.
After 1803, British Government managed Temple directly; by Regulation IV of 1809, management made over to Raja of Khurda (now Raja of Puri) as hereditary superintendent due to family connection.
Government intervened multiple times in last century and a half due to mismanagement, administering secular affairs directly via officers; Raja executed power of attorney divesting himself of powers.

Puri Shri Jagannath Temple Administration Act, No. XIV of 1952 passed for Special Officer to prepare record of rights and duties of sevaks, pujaris etc.; Special Officer submitted report on March 15, 1954 disclosing serious mismanagement.
Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954 (No. 11 of 1955) passed in consequence of mismanagement report.
Father of present appellant filed writ petition O.J.C. No. 321 of 1955 in Orissa High Court challenging constitutionality of the Act; appellant substituted on father's death.
Orissa High Court judgment and order dated April 30, 1958 upheld Act except s.28(2)(f), which was struck down; certificate granted for appeal to Supreme Court.
Petitioner initially claimed Temple as private property; conceded before High Court it is public temple, properties of deity not Raja.
Raja of Puri has two-fold connection: (1) adya sevak (chief servant) with certain rights/privileges; (2) sole superintendent of secular management.
Record of rights prepared under 1952 Act; appellant claimed Act takes away perquisites found belonging to him therein.
Temple occupies unique position in Orissa and India due to vast assets, all-India pilgrims, complicated nitis/seva affecting millions.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954 is unconstitutional under Article 14 as discriminatory by singling out the Temple for special legislation when general Orissa Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1952 applies to others.
Whether the Act deprives appellant of property (Temple or right of superintendence/management) without compensation, violating Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31(2).
Whether the Act unreasonably restricts appellant's rights as adya sevak, violating Article 19(1)(f) not saved by Article 19(5).
Whether specific provisions like s.15(1), s.21 etc. interfere with religious affairs or rights of sevaks/adya sevak.

petitioner_arguments.text: Temple is private property of Raja; Act deprives without compensation violating Art.19(1)(f). (Given up before HC)
Raja has sole right of superintendence/management, which is property; Act takes it away without compensation violating Art.31(2); also unreasonable under Art.19(1)(f)/(5).
Act discriminatory under Art.14 as special legislation for this Temple when general Orissa Hindu Religious Endowments Act 1952 applies to others.
Act takes away perquisites as adya sevak found in record of rights; interferes with rights as chief servant.
Utilisation of Temple funds for alien purposes illegal.
Worshippers of Lord Jagannath form religious denomination under Art.26(d); right to administer via Raja and sevaks taken away.

respondent_arguments.text: Temple is public, not private property of Raja; State has right to ensure proper administration.
History of mismanagement; interventions by rulers/government; 1952 Act and Special Officer report justify new Act.
Temple unique class by itself due to national importance, assets, pilgrims; no discrimination under Art.14.
Act manages only secular affairs; religious per record of rights/custom; Raja remains chairman and adya sevak rights intact.
Temple not of particular denomination but public for all Hindus; management by Hindus.

court_reasoning.text: Temple unique, stands in class by itself justifying special legislation; no violation of Art.14. Analogous to Nathdwara temple case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Temple has unique position in Orissa/India; no other comparable.

court_reasoning.text: Right of superintendence not 'property' under Art.31(2) as no beneficial enjoyment; not acquired by State but office replaced by committee where Raja is chairman. No violation of Art.19(1)(f)/31(2). Parallel to Nathdwara case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sole management extinguished, new body created; not acquisition.

court_reasoning.text: Act does not touch adya sevak rights (religious); preserved by s.8, implied in ss.14,21 etc.; only secular management changed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dichotomy: adya sevak rights intact; superintendent role replaced.

court_reasoning.text: S.15(1) only secular duty to arrange proper performance per record of rights; no interference with religious rites.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Secular provision of materials/supervision of duties.

court_reasoning.text: Arts.26(d),27,28 not applicable; no proper pleading of denomination; management remains with Hindus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Defective pleadings; Temple public for all Hindus.

court_reasoning.text: Other attacked sections (11,19,21,21A,30,30A) valid as ancillary to valid committee constitution; 30A not decided now.

holdings.text: Act constitutional; not discriminatory under Art.14 as Temple unique class.
Removal of sole superintendence not acquisition of property; no violation of Art.19(1)(f)/31(2).
Adya sevak rights untouched; Act only affects secular management.
No violation of Arts.26,27,28 due to defective pleadings.
Specific provisions valid as they regulate secular affairs only.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tilkayat Shri Govindlalji v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Temple management Act valid despite special legislation for unique temple; no acquisition under Art.31(2); single institution as class by itself under Art.14.

statutes_cited.name: Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954 (No. 11 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vests secular management in Committee; preserves adya sevak rights; challenged but upheld as constitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1952 (No. 11 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: General law; deemed part of 1954 Act; record of rights basis for sevas.

statutes_cited.name: Puri Shri Jagannath Temple Administration Act, 1952 (No. XIV of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: For Special Officer report on mismanagement leading to 1954 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenges to Act under these rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Regulation IV of 1809
statutes_cited.relevance: Conferred hereditary superintendence on Raja post-British conquest.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the constitutionality of the Shri Jagannath Temple Act, 1954 except for the provision already struck down by High Court; Act validly reorganises secular management of the unique public Temple without violating fundamental rights.

key_quotes.text: the Temple occupies a unique position in the State of Orissa and is a temple of national importance and no other temple in that State can compare with it stands in a class by itself
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: all that has happened in the present case is that the sole right of the appellant to manage the property has been extinguished and in its place another body for the purpose of the administration of the property of the Temple has been created.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the Act does not affect even the rights, privileges and perquisites of sevaks. If so, in the absence of express provision, it cannot possibly be argued that the Act affects rights, privileges and perquisites of adya sevak.
key_quotes.speaker: court
